other.value:
If the 3 travel ban items are highly correlated and show good internal reliability, then they will be averaged to form one variable.

We may examine if prior knowledge of virus would moderate the effect.

We may exclude participants who wrote obviously irrelevant or nonsensible responses in the open-ended boxes.

Open-ended responses may be coded by research assistants to examine anti-Chinese sentiments.

sample.value: We aim to have 250 participants in the study, which will provide stable estimate for correlation (Schonbrodt & Perugini, 2013) and 80% to detect r = .18. We will run 280 people on MTurk in anticipation for data exclusion.

analyses.value: We will run 3 regression models for each of the three travel ban levels as DV (Wuhan, China, and Asia). Predictors will be Perceived Infectability and Germ Aversion entered simultaneously.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who indicated that they responded randomly in a randomness check. We will also exclude participants who did not pass an attention check.

dependent.value:
Support for travel bans:
Participants will rate their agreement with the following statements (1= strongly disagree; 7= strongly agree)
--The US government should impose a travel ban to prevent travelers from Wuhan, China from entering US.
--The US government should impose a travel ban to prevent travelers from any parts of China from entering US.
--The US government should impose a travel ban to prevent travelers from any parts of Asia from entering US.

Perceived Vulnerability to Disease (PVD) has two subscales: Perceived Infectability and Germ Aversion
Participants will rate their agreement with the following statements (1= strongly disagree; 7= strongly agree)

Perceived infectability
--In general, I am very susceptible to colds, flu, and other infectious diseases.
--I am unlikely to catch a cold, flu, or other illness, even if it is ‘going around.’
--If an illness is ‘going around’, I will get it.
--My immune system protects me from most illnesses that other people get.
--I am more likely than the people around me to catch an infectious disease.
--My past experiences make me believe I am not likely to get sick even when my friends are sick.
--I have a history of susceptibility to infectious disease.

Germ aversion:
--I prefer to wash my hands pretty soon after shaking someone’s hand.
--I avoid using public bathrooms. (changed from public telephones in original item to bathrooms)
--I do not like to write with a pencil someone else has obviously chewed on.
--I dislike wearing used clothes because you do not know what the last person who wore it was like.
--I am comfortable sharing a water bottle with a friend.
--It really bothers me when people sneeze without covering their mouths.
--It does not make me anxious to be around sick people.
--My hands do not feel dirty after touching door handles. (changed from money in original item to door handles)

conditions.value: This is a correlational study. Participants will complete all measures.

hypothesis.value:
Previous research has shown that salience of pathogen can increase prejudice towards foreign outgroups. At the current moment (January 23, 2020), there is an outbreak of coronavirus (Wuhan virus) in Asia that originated from Wuhan, China. This outbreak may stir potential biases against Chinese people, particularly among those who have greater aversion to germs. This may lead them to support measures to prevent entry to US. 

Participants will first read a short background about the Wuhan virus. Then they will indicate if they have heard of it before or not. Participants will then write freely how they feel about the situation and what they think the government should do. Then, they will rate their support for travel bans on people coming from China and Asia. Finally, participants will complete the perceived vulnerability to disease scale. 

I predict that germ aversion will positively predict support for travel bans that prevent travelers from China and Asia broadly from coming into the US.

attributes.title: Increasing Pro-Environmental Behavior Through Implementation Intentions

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Increasing Pro-Environmental Behavior Through Implementation Intentions

other.value:
Covariates: 
We will measure two potential confounding constructs and include them in the analysis in case of differences between the groups (see "Analyses" for details): Social desirability will be measured using the “Inventar zur Erfassung von zwei Faktoren sozialer Erwünschtheit” (Musch, Brockhaus, & Röder, 2002); the questionnaire includes two facets of social desirability, namely self-deceptive enhancement and impression management. We will combine the items for both scales separately using sum scores, like Musch et al. (2002). 

In addition, we will measure participants’ attitude towards various environmental issues using items by Chebrah (2009). The items will be combined by computing a sum score for every participant. As described above, we will include these as covariates in our analysis without any preceding analyses on group differences. 


References:

Chrebah, B. (2009). Umweltbewusstsein und Umweltverhalten: ein Vergleich von deutschen und syrischen Studierenden (Doctoral dissertation, Universität Oldenburg).

Faul, F., Erdfelder, E., Lang, A. G., & Buchner, A. (2007). G* Power 3: A flexible statistical power analysis program for the social, behavioral, and biomedical sciences. Behavior research methods, 39, 175-191.

Gollwitzer, P. M. (1993). Goal achievement: The role of intentions. European review of social psychology, 4, 141-185.

Gollwitzer, P. M. (1999). Implementation intentions: strong effects of simple plans. American psychologist, 54, 493.

Gollwitzer, P. M., & Sheeran, P. (2006). Implementation intentions and goal achievement: A meta‐analysis of effects and processes. Advances in experimental social psychology, 38, 69-119.

Holland, R. W., Aarts, H., & Langendam, D. (2006). Breaking and creating habits on the working floor: A field-experiment on the power of implementation intentions. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, 42, 776-783.

Musch, J., Brockhaus, R., & Bröder, A. (2002). Ein Inventar zur Erfassung von zwei Faktoren sozialer Erwünschtheit. Diagnostica.

Toli, A., Webb, T. L., & Hardy, G. E. (2016). Does forming implementation intentions help people with mental health problems to achieve goals? A meta‐analysis of experimental studies with clinical and analogue samples. British Journal of Clinical Psychology, 55, 69-90.

sample.value: We will collect data from N = 100 Participants. Our sample size is based on a power analysis conducted using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). We aimed for a power of .80 to detect a small effect of the interaction between measurement and group (partial eta-squared = .08). To observe an effect of that size with a power of .80 in a mixed design, a sample size of at least N = 96 participants is required.

analyses.value:
We will conduct a 2 (group: implementation intentions vs. goal intentions, between participants) x 2 (time of measurement: pre vs. post, within participants) mixed design analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) on participants’ self-reported use of disposable cups during the preceding week. Participants’ scores on the questionnaire measuring their attitude towards various environmental issues (see "Other" for details) will be included as covariates in the analysis, as we expect the effect of the intervention to differ depending on participants’ attitudes. 

To test our hypothesis, we will inspect the time of measurement x group interaction using the standard alpha < .05 criterion: The decrease in the dependent variable should be stronger in the group that worked on implementation intentions compared to the group that worked on goal intentions. In case of a significant interaction between the two factors, we will inspect the direction of the effect graphically. In addition, we will conduct two paired t-tests analyzing the change between pre and post-measurement in the experimental group and the control group separately, using a Bonferroni-corrected significance level of alpha < .025.Thereby, we will determine whether the effect is limited to one group or whether there is a significant change in both groups. 

In addition, we will test for differences in social desirability between the two groups (measured on two dimensions, see "Other" for details) using t-tests. In case that one or both variables differ between the groups, they will be included as covariates in our main analysis. All covariates will be z-standardized.

outliers.value:
Exclusion of participants: 
We will only include participants who completed the whole study during the course of two weeks: The participants will receive an invitation to participate in part two exactly one week after completing part one. We will only include subjects in the sample if they participate in part two not later than one week after receiving the invitation (i.e., two weeks after part one). 
Furthermore, we will only include participants who state that they used at least one disposable cup during the last week in the pre-measurement: At the beginning of the experiment, participants will be asked whether they use disposable cups at all and if they do, whether they want to reduce their use. For participants who answer negatively to either of these questions, the experiment ends and naturally, they will not be included in the sample. Since implementation intentions aim to help people to translate their goals into behavior, the intervention is pointless for participants who do not intend to change their behavior. In addition, participants who do not type anything or only something completely unrelated to the topic during the intervention will be excluded from the sample. Finally, we will exclude participants who state that their data should not be used in the final questionnaire.

dependent.value: Our main-dependent variable is participants’ self-reported number of disposable cups, bought during the course of the last week (i.e., pre-measurement: The week before the intervention; post-measurement: the week before completing the second part of the questionnaire, i.e., 1-2 weeks later). We will ask participants to retrospectively estimate the absolute number of disposable cups they bought during the course of the last seven days.

conditions.value:
The participants will be randomly assigned to either the control condition (working on goal intentions) or the experimental condition (working on implementation intentions).

The experimental group will formulate implementation intentions on five different scenarios: They will be presented with five different problems that could prevent them from using fewer disposable cups: 
Problem 1: I forgot my reusable cup at home. 
Problem 2: I don’t own a reusable cup. 
Problem 3: I don’t have time to stay in and have a hot drink sitting in a café. 
Problem 4: I doubt that avoiding disposable cups does something good for the environment. 
Problem 5: I am in a group of people, who are all buying a hot drink to take away in a disposable cup and now I would like to buy a hot drink, too. 

In addition, participants get the opportunity to add up to five more problems with regard to this topic. Then, they will formulate implementation intentions (see Gollwitzer, 1999, for an introduction) on how to deal with these problematic situations. 

The control group will work on goal intentions instead. They will be asked to type the goal (“I want to use fewer disposable cups” ) into a given textbox five times. Then, they will get the opportunity to type it again up to another five times.

hypothesis.value:
In previous studies, implementation intentions, plans formulated in an if-then format, have been used to change people’s behavior in various domains (e.g., Gollwitzer, 1993, 1999, 2006; Tolli, Web, & Hardy, 2016; see Gollwitzer & Sheeran, 2006, for a meta-analysis and review). Notably, implementation intentions have also been used to promote environmentally-friendly behaviors (e.g., Holland, Aarts, & Langendam, 2006). 

The present study aims at reducing people’s use of disposable cups through an intervention where participants formulate implementation intentions regarding this behavior. In an online experiment, participants will be randomly assigned to two different conditions (experimental condition: implementation intentions; control condition: goal intentions) both working on the topic of disposable cups. Both groups will be presented with an informational text concerning the average use of disposable cups in Germany and the resulting environmental consequences. Next, participants in the experimental condition will formulate implementation intentions regarding their use of disposable cups (see Gollwitzer, 1999, for an introduction). Participants in the control condition will work on goal intentions regarding the same topic (see "Conditions" for details on both conditions).

We will measure participants’ use of disposable cups (self-report) before and after the intervention: Participants will be asked to estimate their use of disposable cups during the past week right before the intervention and in a short follow-up questionnaire they will receive one week after the intervention. 

Hypothesis: Participants in the implementation intention condition show greater reduction in their use of disposable cups compared to participants in the goal intention condition.

attributes.title: Exploring parents' experiences of their children's trichotillomania
attributes.description: This project investigates how parental self-blame for their children's trichotillomania is related to expressed emotion towards the children. It also includes questions on subjective trichotillomania knowledge and severity and how these factors relate to expressed emotion and self-blame in parents. An open-ended question will allow for additional qualitative insight into parents' perceptions of their children's trichotillomania. This is the first project to investigate these factors and relationships in parents of hair-pulling children.

q1.value: Exploring parents' experiences of their children's trichotillomania

q3.value: This project investigates how parental self-blame for their children's trichotillomania is related to expressed emotion towards the children. It also includes questions on subjective trichotillomania knowledge and severity and how these factors relate to expressed emotion and self-blame in parents. An open-ended question will allow for additional qualitative insight into parents' perceptions of their children's trichotillomania. This is the first project to investigate these factors and relationships in parents of hair-pulling children.

q4.value:
1) Higher self-blame scores will predict higher EE scores (directional).
2) Mothers are hypothesised to score higher on EE and self-blame measures than fathers (directional).
3) The investigation of subjective knowledge and severity of TTM with self-blame and EE will be purely exploratory.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Data is collected online through the University of Glasgow's secure experimentum website. Participants are parents who have children with trichotillomania. Participants are recruited via email and online advertisements. Recruiting started in December 2019 and will end no later than 19th March 2020.

q13.value: We aim for a sample size of 75 participants.

q14.value: Based on previously reported statistics, an effect size of .4 was used to calculate the required sample size for this study to be sufficiently powered (power = .95; significance level = .05), resulting in a desired sample size of at least 75 participants.

question.value:
-	Parents' expressed emotion towards their child(ren): The Family Questionnaire (Widemann, Rayki, Feinstein, & Hahlweg, 2002): measures expressed emotions by the use of two subscales (criticism and emotional over-involvement). It is designed to be used by parents of children with mental disorders. The instructions were altered to read “… how often you have reacted to [your child] in this way” instead of “…how often you have reacted to the patient this way” to make the instructions more relatable and less stigmatising. All items are used.
-	Parents' self-blame for their child(ren)'s trichotillomania: Parent Self-Stigma Scale (Eaton, Ohan, Stritzke, & Corrigan, 2018): measures parental self-stigma for their child’s illness. Only the self-blame subscale will be used for the present research, reducing the number of items to six.
Multiple linear regression will be used - see attachment for exact analysis code

q22.value: Outliers beyond a 3 standard deviation will be removed from analysis.

q23.value: incomplete data sets will be removed from analysis

attributes.title: P3 - Roediger et al. (1995): False memories (Experiment 2)Datei

summary.value: This project implements Experiment 2 of Roediger and McDermott (1995)- Creating false memories: Remembering words not presented in lists- as an online experiment. The main purpose is to replicate this study .The project will be carried out during a semester of study at the Universitäre Fernstudien Schweiz in Modul 4 - ICT-Information & Communication Technology in Forschung und Lehre.

attributes.title: Replikation Impliziter Assoziationstest (IAT)
attributes.description: Replikationsstudie IAT für M04 Kurs an der Fernuni im HS2019

summary.value: Dieses Projekt implementiert die Replikation des Experiments 3 der bereits publizierten Studie "Der implizite Assoziationstest (IAT) von Greenwald, McGhee und Schwartz (1998)" als online Studie. Das Projekt ist Teil des Leistungsnachweises im Modul M4 "Informations- und Kommunikationstechnologien in Lehre und Forschung (ICT)" an der Fernuni Schweiz. Das Ziel ist, dass eine lauffähige Version der Studie online abrufbar ist, Pilotdaten damit erhoben und auch ausgewertet werden können. Die Registrierung hat den Zweck, dass andere Studierende prüfen können, wie gut sich mit den zur Verfügung gestellten Ressourcen das Experiment replizieren lässt.

attributes.title: Predicting eyewitness memory accuracy with effort cues and confidence: the effect of time and repetition
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: 42 out of 50 participants have participated in the experiment. None of the interviews have yet been transcribed, nor coded.

dataCollectionDates.value: Start date: September 6th 2019. End date: February 2020. (Data collection)

question2a.value:
Repetition. Two levels (repetition/no repetition). Manipulated between participants.

Time. Two levels (straight after participants have witnessed the event/two weeks later). Manipulated within participants.

question2b.value:
a.	Memory accuracy (correct/incorrect)
b.	Confidence judgments (0%/20%/40%/60%/80%/100% confident)
c.	Effort cue: Hedges (integer)
d.	Effort cue: Word filler (integer)
e.	Effort cue: Non-word fillers (integer)
f.	Effort cue: Delays (integer)
g.	Effort cue: False starts (integer)
h.	Effort cue: Prolongations (integer)
i.	Effort index: Variable computed by adding the effort cues (hedges, word fillers, non-word fillers, delays, false starts and/or prolongations) that have significant unique contribution to memory accuracy. 
j.	Memory quantity (integer)

question10b.value: Participants will arrive at the lab individually and watch a videotape containing a mock crime.  When the film has concluded, participants will be interviewed about what they have seen. The interview will start with an open free recall task (e.g. “what did you see?”), followed by open directed questions (e.g. “how was the perpetrator dressed?”). As the participant responds to the questions, the interviewer will write down the memories on a numbered sheet. Following the interview, the memories that the participant provides will be read aloud by the experiment leader and the participant will then rate his/her confidence for each memory on a scale from 0% to 100% with integers of 20. A short survey assessing demographic question will then be filled out. When the testing is finished, a date will be set for the next interview to be held two weeks later. Participants will then randomly be assigned to either experiment condition ("repetition") or control condition. Participants in the experiment condition will be instructed to fill out a survey online that requests the participant write down everything he/she remembers from the event as detailed as possible. This is done in order to strengthen the partipants’ memories about the event. This survey will be answered four times during the two week-long interval between interview one and two, with intervals ranging between 2-3 days per survey. Participants in the control condition will receive no such instructions. The second session will be carried out identically to the first session, with the exception that no film will be shown this time. Before the second interview starts, participants will also first answer questions about how much they have recalled the events in the video during the two-week interval. The interviews will be videotaped and transcribed verbatim. From this material, statements will be picked out by independent coders, blind to the purpose of the study. Statements will be chosen on the basis of being objectively possible to confirm/reject. For example, the statement “he had a green coat” is an example of such an objectively verifiable statement, whereas “he was feeling cold” is not. Memory accuracy will be coded as correct or incorrect by evaluating the statements; partly correct and partly incorrect answers will be excluded. Effort cues will be coded by following the proceedings by Gustafsson et al. (2019): 1) Delays – a pause longer than two seconds before or during a response; 2) Non-word fillers – interjections and sounds like “hm “, “uh”, etc.; 3) Word fillers – “meaningless” words like “you know “ , “well”, etc. This category also includes self-talk “Let’s see...”; 4) Hedges – word forms that reduce the force of an assertion, allow for exceptions, or avoid commitment, such as  ”I think”, ”maybe”. Additionally, we will code two new variables, inspired from psycholinguistic research (e.g. Clark & Fox Tree, 2002, Fox Tree & Clark, 1997): 5) False starts – initiated expressions that are stopped and then started anew; 6) Prolongations – prolonged pronunciations of a word. Interrater reliability will be calculated with Pearson’s correlation as well as percentages of exact overlap. Interratings of r = .70 and exact overlap = 60% will be set as threshold levels, in which lower values will lead to re-coding of the variable.

question4b.value: We have planned a sample of N=50 with 25 participants in each group (repetition/control). Based on a pilot study, we expect each participant to provide about 70 statements (i.e. memories) about the witnessed event, at each interview. This will yield a total sample size of about 7000 memories.

question5b.value: Participants will be recruited at Stockholm University and other universities in the Stockholm area (KTH, Karolinska Institute, Södertörn university), as well as from the website www.studentkaninen.se. Posters will be placed at these locations to advertise the study. Data collection will be performed in a lab at Stockholm University with videotaped interviews.

question6b.value:
A power analysis for a linear multiple regression with 7 predictors (accuracy, time, repetition and their interactions), a medium effect size and 95% power will require N=153. The planned study is expected to yield a sample over 45 times greater. Although the analyses we expect to run are multilevel rather than a linear regression, the sample size should result in adequate power. According to Snijders (2005), the sample size at the top level (memories, in this case) is the most important in multilevel models, of which our sample is expected to be N≈7000. 

We will use a greater sample size than required by the power analysis as we want to have data from several different participants.

question7b.value: Data collection will be terminated when 50 participants have completed both the first and second interview. Data will not be coded nor analyzed until all observations have been collected.

question8b.value:
We will exclude participants who:
1) fail to complete both interviews
2) do not have correct or corrected-to-normal vision
3) correctly recognize any of the actors in the stimulus material (staged crime film)
4) do not complete the repetition task despite being assigned to the repetition group
5) do not speak fluent Swedish
6) are underage (under 18 years old)

question7c.value: Listwise deletion will be employed for missing data. This is certain to be the case for calculations of hypothesis 3-5 and interaction 4, as it feasible to obtain effort cues for all statements, but not confidence judgments (see Lindholm et al., 2018; Gustafsson et al., 2019).

question9c.value: Effort index: see “Methods – description of essential elements”

question1a.value:
Hypothesis 1: We expect a main effect of accuracy on retrieval effort: Incorrect memories will be more effortful to retrieve compared to correct memories. 

Hypothesis 2: We expect a main effect of repetition on retrieval effort: Participants that have engaged in repeated memory retrieval (repetition condition) will report memories with less effort in an interview two weeks after having viewed an event, compared to participants with no memory repetition (control condition).

Hypothesis 3: We expect a main effect of accuracy on confidence: Participants will be more confident in correct memories compared to incorrect memories. 

Hypothesis 4: We expect a main effect of repetition on confidence: Participants that have engaged in repeated memory retrieval (repetition condition) will be more confident in their memories reported in an interview two weeks later, compared to participants with no memory repetition (control condition).

Hypothesis 5: We expect that effort cues will mediate the relation between memory accuracy and confidence.

Hypothesis 6: We expect a main effect of repetition on memory quantity: Participants that have engaged in repeated memory retrieval (repetition condition) will report more memories in an interview two weeks after having viewed an event, compared to participants with no memory repetition (control condition).

question2a.value:
Interaction 1: We expect an interaction between repetition and time on retrieval effort: Participants that have engaged in repeated memory retrieval (repetition condition) will report memories with less effort in an interview two weeks later, compared to directly after an event. Meanwhile, participants that have not engaged in repeated memory retrieval (control condition) will report memories with more effort in an interview two weeks later, compared to directly after the event.

Interaction 2: We expect an interaction between accuracy and repetition on retrieval effort: There will be a smaller difference in retrieval effort between correct and incorrect memories reported at an interview two weeks after a viewed event for participants that have engaged in repeated memory retrieval (repetition condition) compared to participants that have not engaged in repeated memory retrieval (control condition).

Interaction 3: We expect an interaction between repetition, time and accuracy on retrieval effort: The difference in effort in reported correct and incorrect memories will be smaller for participants that have engaged in repeated memory retrieval (repetition condition) two weeks after having viewed an event, compared to directly after an event. Meanwhile, there will be no difference in effort in reported correct and incorrect memories over time for participants that have not engaged in repeated memory retrieval (control condition).

Interaction 4: We expect an interaction between repetition and time on confidence: Participants that have engaged in repeated memory retrieval (repetition condition) will be more confident in reported memories in an interview two weeks later, compared to directly after the event. Meanwhile, participants that have not engaged in repeated memory retrieval (control condition) will be less confident in reported memories in an interview two weeks later compared to compared to directly after the event.

question3a.value:
Manipulation of time will be carried out by interviewing participants twice. No manipulation check is needed, as participants must take part in both interviews in order to fulfill participation in the study. 

Manipulation of repetition will be carried out by having participants in the experimental condition complete an online survey that requests the participants to write down everything they remember from the event in as much detail as possible (to be completed four times during the interval between the first and second interview session). This manipulation could therefore be said to contain an inherent manipulation check, as those who complete the survey must bring back (i.e. repeatedly retrieve) the memories in order to report what they have seen. However, participants in the control group might also spontaneously think about the event repeatedly, even without explicit instructions. Therefore, control questions will be asked about how often and much time the participants spent thinking about the events in the video during the interval between the two sessions.

question5a.value:
Eyewitness reports are common and often critical sources of information in the event of an accident or a criminal offense, not the least in courtroom decision-making (Wells, Memon & Penrod, 2006). However, research has demonstrated that people have great difficulty in judging the accuracy of others’ memories (Lindholm, 2005; 2008a; 2008b). While lying is one issue in eyewitness testimonies (see DePaulo et al., 2003; Vrij, Fischer & Blank, 2017; Sporer & Schwandt, 2006), another major source of eyewitness errors is when a witness gives an honest report but remember things incorrectly. For example, there are now many reports on eyewitnesses who honestly, but mistakenly, have identified innocent people as crime culprits, sending them to long prison sentences and sometimes to death row (Garret, 2011; “Innocence project”, 2018). Despite the relevance of obtaining a method to differentiate between sincere correct and incorrect eyewitness memories, relatively little research has touched upon the subject of evaluating sincere eyewitness recall, and there is currently no satisfying model serving this purpose. Recently however, Lindholm, Jönsson & Tullio-Liuzza (2018) proposed a new strategy in which memory accuracy was found to be related to signs of retrieval effort in witnesses’ responses. The results were replicated in a later study (Gustafsson, Lindholm & Jönsson, 2019). The current study aims to replicate these previous results. Furthermore, this study will investigate the effects of time and repetition on memory retrieval effort. The purpose is to continue the evaluation of the use of effort cues to predict memory accuracy and to further our understanding about judgments of our memories.

There are two major reasons for examining the effects of time and repetition on memory retrieval effort. The first reason is because time and repetition can have detrimental effects on eyewitness reports and subsequent evaluations of them. It is not uncommon for witnesses to be interviewed several times, with days or weeks passing between interviews, which can lead to changed statements (i.e. memory distortions), and increased confidence in details of witnessed events (see Garret, 2011; Schmolck, Buffalo & Squire, 2000). These changes impair the accuracy of evaluations of eyewitness reports. The increased confidence is problematic as it is seldom accompanied by an increase in accuracy. That is, participants tend to get more confident in their memories over time, regardless of whether the memory is correct or wrong (Odinot, Wolters, & van Koppen, 2009; Shaw, 1996; Shaw & McClure, 1996; Wixted, Mickes, Clark, Gronlund & Roediger, 2015). A likely explanation for this phenomenon is an increased ease in retrieving memories, as the memories will be strengthened by repeated retrieval over time (see Odinot et al., 2009). As a result, confidence becomes an unreliable method for eyewitness evaluation in these situations. It is noteworthy, as confidence judgments are used in courts to judge eyewitness memory accuracy (Boyce, Beaudry & Lindsay, 2007, see also Wixted & Wells, 2017).

The second reason for examining the effect of time and repetition on retrieval effort is due to the intricate relationship between memory accuracy, retrieval effort and confidence judgments. According to the theory of cue-utilization (Koriat, 1997; 2006), metacognitive judgments such as confidence are based on implicit inferences from processing cues that arise when a memory is produced. For example, previous studies have shown that retrieval ease, is negatively correlated with memory accuracy. That is, quick responses are more often correct than slower responses (e.g. Ackerman & Koriat, 2011; Brewer, Caon, Todd & Weber, 2006; Koriat & Ackerman, 2010; Weidemann & Kahana, 2016; for a review, see Brewer & Weber, 2008). Additionally, people are more confident in answers that quickly come to mind. For example, Kelley & Lindsay (1993) showed that manipulating retrieval ease affects confidence regardless of accuracy, indicating that the ease with which a memory is retrieved serves as a basis for judging its accuracy. 

Recently, Lindholm et al (2019) identified additional cues of retrieval ease (or rather, retrieval effort), such as use of fillers (“eh”, “uhm”), which were also related to memory accuracy and confidence. They also found that the retrieval effort cues better predicted accuracy compared to confidence. These results were later replicated by Gustafsson et al., (2019).  Furthermore, both studies found mediating effects of effort cues between memory accuracy and confidence. As the investigation of effort cues is a recent endeavor, it is still unknown how these effort cues relate to accuracy and confidence over time, and to what extent repeated memory retrieval affects these relations. Such an examination is valuable as it will further illuminate the extent of which people rely on retrieval cues in making metacognitive judgments (such as a judgment of confidence). Additionally, it will also serve to elucidate the relationship between memory retrieval effort and memory accuracy.

The hypotheses in this study are derived from current research about metacognition, the effect of time on memory, and memory retrieval:

Hypothesis 1 is based on the main findings by Lindholm et al., (2018) and Gustafsson et al. (2019). The hypothesis is also supported by evidence regarding the relationship between retrieval ease and accuracy (Ackerman & Koriat, 2011; Brewer, Caon, Todd & Weber, 2006; Brewer & Weber, 2008; Kelley & Lindsay, 1993; Koriat & Ackerman, 2010; Weidemann & Kahana, 2016). 

Hypothesis 2 comes from research showing that repeatedly retrieving memories strengthen them (Antony, Ferreira, Norman & Wimber, 2017; Rowland, 2014), which should in turn lead to less effort in recalling them. Furthermore, this should also increase the confidence in them (Hypothesis 4).
Hypothesis 3 follow from previous studies demonstrating the relationship between confidence and memory accuracy (for reviews, see Brewer & Weber, 2008; Roediger & DeSoto; 2014; Roediger, Wixted & DeSoto, 2012; Wixted, Mickes, Clark, Gronlund & Roediger, 2015; Wixted & Wells, 2017). 

Hypothesis 5 follows from our previous studies demonstrating a mediating effect of effort cues between memory accuracy and confidence (Lindholm et al., 2018; Gustafsson et al., 2019).

Hypothesis 6 follow from studies showing that time leads to a weakening and forgetting of memories that are not activated (Schacter, 1999; Wixted, 2004) whereas repeating memories strengthen them and increases their chances of being successfully recalled (see Hypothesis 2).

Interaction 1 follows from the arguments for Hypothesis 2 and 6. That is, participants that repeatedly retrieve their memories over time will require less effort to recall them because repetition facilitates recall, whereas participants that do not recall their memories over time will require more effort to recall them because memory weakening impairs recall.

Interaction 2 & 3 suggest that difference in retrieval effort in recalling correct and incorrect memories will diminish over time for participants in the repetition condition, but not for participants in the control condition. The result for participants in the repetition condition is expected as both incorrect and correct memories will be strengthened by the repetition. Specifically, the recall of correct memories is believed to already be close to a minimum amount of effort (e.g. no delays, no hedges) at the first interview session, which means it cannot become much less effortful by repetition (i.e. a floor effect). The recall of incorrect memories are instead believed to be effortful to retrieve at the first interview session, but will then become easier to recall after the repetition. This means that the incorrect memories will approximate the retrieval effort of the correct memories after the repetition. Conversely, for participants in the control condition all memories are expected to become more difficult to recall at the second interview due to a general memory weakening, which should preserve the relative difference in memory effort between correct and incorrect memories.

question6a.value:
Effects of repetition: Despite evidence supporting Hypothesis 2 and 4 (and Interaction 1-4), some studies have found diverging results. Knutsson, Allwood & Johansson (2011) and Odinot et al. (2013) used repeated questioning to investigate the confidence-memory accuracy relationship and found no effects of repetition.

Effects of time: In an unpublished study, Lindholm compared confidence in eyewitness testimonies with a one-week delay between two interview sessions. The results showed no effect of time on confidence, which contrasts with our expected Interactions 1, 3 and 4. Additionally, Wixted, Read & Lindsay (2016) argue that confidence is good across time for eyewitness identifications. Although eyewitness identifications differ from verbal eyewitness testimonies, it is nonetheless evidence that does not conform to our expected effects.

Effects of time on memory strength: We expect participant in the control group to experience forgetting and weakening of their memories during the interval between interview one and two. This is expected to be consistent throughout memories and therefore preserve an intact relation between memory retrieval effort and memory accuracy. However, it is known that people can strategically regulate which memories they present in free recall tasks (Goldsmith, Koriat & Pansky, 2005; Koriat & Goldsmith, 1996). Therefore, participants may choose to withhold those memories which they find weak and subsequently effortful to recall, with the goal to avoid giving out incorrect information. This would invalidate Interactions 2 and 3—and lead to a smaller effect for Hypotheses 2 and 4—by resulting in a smaller difference in the relation between memory retrieval effort and memory accuracy for the control group. That is, participants in the control group would then show the same trend over time as the repetition group: incorrect and correct memories become more similarly effortful to retrieve. If this is the case, it should also be evident in Hypothesis 6 as a particularly large effect, as fewer memories would be presented in the control group.

For the other variables, see “Methods – description of essential elements”.

The purpose is to continue the evaluation of the use of effort cues to predict memory accuracy and to further our understanding about judgments of our memories.

There are two major reasons for examining the effects of time and repetition on memory retrieval effort. The first reason is because time and repetition can have detrimental effects on eyewitness reports and subsequent evaluations of them. It is not uncommon for witnesses to be interviewed several times, with days or weeks passing between interviews, which can lead to changed statements (i.e. memory distortions), and increased confidence in details of witnessed events (see Garret, 2011; Schmolck, Buffalo & Squire, 2000). These changes impair the accuracy of evaluations of eyewitness reports. The increased confidence is problematic as it is seldom accompanied by an increase in accuracy. That is, participants tend to get more confident in their memories over time, regardless of whether the memory is correct or wrong (Odinot, Wolters, & van Koppen, 2009; Shaw, 1996; Shaw & McClure, 1996; Wixted, Mickes, Clark, Gronlund & Roediger, 2015). A likely explanation for this phenomenon is an increased ease in retrieving memories, as the memories will be strengthened by repeated retrieval over time (see Odinot et al., 2009). As a result, confidence becomes an unreliable method for eyewitness evaluation in these situations. It is noteworthy, as confidence judgments are used in courts to judge eyewitness memory accuracy (Boyce, Beaudry & Lindsay, 2007, see also Wixted & Wells, 2017).

The second reason for examining the effect of time and repetition on retrieval effort is due to the intricate relationship between memory accuracy, retrieval effort and confidence judgments. According to the theory of cue-utilization (Koriat, 1997; 2006), metacognitive judgments such as confidence are based on implicit inferences from processing cues that arise when a memory is produced. For example, previous studies have shown that retrieval ease, is negatively correlated with memory accuracy. That is, quick responses are more often correct than slower responses (e.g. Ackerman & Koriat, 2011; Brewer, Caon, Todd & Weber, 2006; Koriat & Ackerman, 2010; Weidemann & Kahana, 2016; for a review, see Brewer & Weber, 2008). Additionally, people are more confident in answers that quickly come to mind. For example, Kelley & Lindsay (1993) showed that manipulating retrieval ease affects confidence regardless of accuracy, indicating that the ease with which a memory is retrieved serves as a basis for judging its accuracy. 

Recently, Lindholm et al (2019) identified additional cues of retrieval ease (or rather, retrieval effort), such as use of fillers (“eh”, “uhm”), which were also related to memory accuracy and confidence. They also found that the retrieval effort cues better predicted accuracy compared to confidence. These results were later replicated by Gustafsson et al., (2019).  Furthermore, both studies found mediating effects of effort cues between memory accuracy and confidence. As the investigation of effort cues is a recent endeavor, it is still unknown how these effort cues relate to accuracy and confidence over time, and to what extent repeated memory retrieval affects these relations. Such an examination is valuable as it will further illuminate the extent of which people rely on retrieval cues in making metacognitive judgments (such as a judgment of confidence). Additionally, it will also serve to elucidate the relationship between memory retrieval effort and memory accuracy.

The hypotheses in this study are derived from current research about metacognition, the effect of time on memory, and memory retrieval:

Hypothesis 1 is based on the main findings by Lindholm et al., (2018) and Gustafsson et al. (2019). The hypothesis is also supported by evidence regarding the relationship between retrieval ease and accuracy (Ackerman & Koriat, 2011; Brewer, Caon, Todd & Weber, 2006; Brewer & Weber, 2008; Kelley & Lindsay, 1993; Koriat & Ackerman, 2010; Weidemann & Kahana, 2016). 

Hypothesis 2 comes from research showing that repeatedly retrieving memories strengthen them (Antony, Ferreira, Norman & Wimber, 2017; Rowland, 2014), which should in turn lead to less effort in recalling them. Furthermore, this should also increase the confidence in them (Hypothesis 4).
Hypothesis 3 follow from previous studies demonstrating the relationship between confidence and memory accuracy (for reviews, see Brewer & Weber, 2008; Roediger & DeSoto; 2014; Roediger, Wixted & DeSoto, 2012; Wixted, Mickes, Clark, Gronlund & Roediger, 2015; Wixted & Wells, 2017). 

Hypothesis 5 follows from our previous studies demonstrating a mediating effect of effort cues between memory accuracy and confidence (Lindholm et al., 2018; Gustafsson et al., 2019).

Hypothesis 6 follow from studies showing that time leads to a weakening and forgetting of memories that are not activated (Schacter, 1999; Wixted, 2004) whereas repeating memories strengthen them and increases their chances of being successfully recalled (see Hypothesis 2).

Interaction 1 follows from the arguments for Hypothesis 2 and 6. That is, participants that repeatedly retrieve their memories over time will require less effort to recall them because repetition facilitates recall, whereas participants that do not recall their memories over time will require more effort to recall them because memory weakening impairs recall.

Interaction 2 & 3 suggest that difference in retrieval effort in recalling correct and incorrect memories will diminish over time for participants in the repetition condition, but not for participants in the control condition. The result for participants in the repetition condition is expected as both incorrect and correct memories will be strengthened by the repetition. Specifically, the recall of correct memories is believed to already be close to a minimum amount of effort (e.g. no delays, no hedges) at the first interview session, which means it cannot become much less effortful by repetition (i.e. a floor effect). The recall of incorrect memories are instead believed to be effortful to retrieve at the first interview session, but will then become easier to recall after the repetition. This means that the incorrect memories will approximate the retrieval effort of the correct memories after the repetition. Conversely, for participants in the control condition all memories are expected to become more difficult to recall at the second interview due to a general memory weakening, which should preserve the relative difference in memory effort between correct and incorrect memories.
registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question6a:
Effects of repetition: Despite evidence supporting Hypothesis 2 and 4 (and Interaction 1-4), some studies have found diverging results. Knutsson, Allwood & Johansson (2011) and Odinot et al. (2013) used repeated questioning to investigate the confidence-memory accuracy relationship and found no effects of repetition.

Effects of time: In an unpublished study, Lindholm compared confidence in eyewitness testimonies with a one-week delay between two interview sessions. The results showed no effect of time on confidence, which contrasts with our expected Interactions 1, 3 and 4. Additionally, Wixted, Read & Lindsay (2016) argue that confidence is good across time for eyewitness identifications. Although eyewitness identifications differ from verbal eyewitness testimonies, it is nonetheless evidence that does not conform to our expected effects.

Effects of time on memory strength: We expect participant in the control group to experience forgetting and weakening of their memories during the interval between interview one and two. This is expected to be consistent throughout memories and therefore preserve an intact relation between memory retrieval effort and memory accuracy. However, it is known that people can strategically regulate which memories they present in free recall tasks (Goldsmith, Koriat & Pansky, 2005; Koriat & Goldsmith, 1996). Therefore, participants may choose to withhold those memories which they find weak and subsequently effortful to recall, with the goal to avoid giving out incorrect information. This would invalidate Interactions 2 and 3—and lead to a smaller effect for Hypotheses 2 and 4—by resulting in a smaller difference in the relation between memory retrieval effort and memory accuracy for the control group. That is, participants in the control group would then show the same trend over time as the repetition group: incorrect and correct memories become more similarly effortful to retrieve. If this is the case, it should also be evident in Hypothesis 6 as a particularly large effect, as fewer memories would be presented in the control group.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
Repetition. Two levels (repetition/no repetition). Manipulated between participants.

Time. Two levels (straight after participants have witnessed the event/two weeks later). Manipulated within participants.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
a.	Memory accuracy (correct/incorrect)
b.	Confidence judgments (0%/20%/40%/60%/80%/100% confident)
c.	Effort cue: Hedges (integer)
d.	Effort cue: Word filler (integer)
e.	Effort cue: Non-word fillers (integer)
f.	Effort cue: Delays (integer)
g.	Effort cue: False starts (integer)
h.	Effort cue: Prolongations (integer)
i.	Effort index: Variable computed by adding the effort cues (hedges, word fillers, non-word fillers, delays, false starts and/or prolongations) that have significant unique contribution to memory accuracy. 
j.	Memory quantity (integer)
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question7c: Listwise deletion will be employed for missing data. This is certain to be the case for calculations of hypothesis 3-5 and interaction 4, as it feasible to obtain effort cues for all statements, but not confidence judgments (see Lindholm et al., 2018; Gustafsson et al., 2019).
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question9c: Effort index: see “Methods – description of essential elements”
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10: Participants will arrive at the lab individually and watch a videotape containing a mock crime.  When the film has concluded, participants will be interviewed about what they have seen. The interview will start with an open free recall task (e.g. “what did you see?”), followed by open directed questions (e.g. “how was the perpetrator dressed?”). As the participant responds to the questions, the interviewer will write down the memories on a numbered sheet. Following the interview, the memories that the participant provides will be read aloud by the experiment leader and the participant will then rate his/her confidence for each memory on a scale from 0% to 100% with integers of 20. A short survey assessing demographic question will then be filled out. When the testing is finished, a date will be set for the next interview to be held two weeks later. Participants will then randomly be assigned to either experiment condition ("repetition") or control condition. Participants in the experiment condition will be instructed to fill out a survey online that requests the participant write down everything he/she remembers from the event as detailed as possible. This is done in order to strengthen the partipants’ memories about the event. This survey will be answered four times during the two week-long interval between interview one and two, with intervals ranging between 2-3 days per survey. Participants in the control condition will receive no such instructions. The second session will be carried out identically to the first session, with the exception that no film will be shown this time. Before the second interview starts, participants will also first answer questions about how much they have recalled the events in the video during the two-week interval. The interviews will be videotaped and transcribed verbatim. From this material, statements will be picked out by independent coders, blind to the purpose of the study. Statements will be chosen on the basis of being objectively possible to confirm/reject. For example, the statement “he had a green coat” is an example of such an objectively verifiable statement, whereas “he was feeling cold” is not. Memory accuracy will be coded as correct or incorrect by evaluating the statements; partly correct and partly incorrect answers will be excluded. Effort cues will be coded by following the proceedings by Gustafsson et al. (2019): 1) Delays – a pause longer than two seconds before or during a response; 2) Non-word fillers – interjections and sounds like “hm “, “uh”, etc.; 3) Word fillers – “meaningless” words like “you know “ , “well”, etc. This category also includes self-talk “Let’s see...”; 4) Hedges – word forms that reduce the force of an assertion, allow for exceptions, or avoid commitment, such as  ”I think”, ”maybe”. Additionally, we will code two new variables, inspired from psycholinguistic research (e.g. Clark & Fox Tree, 2002, Fox Tree & Clark, 1997): 5) False starts – initiated expressions that are stopped and then started anew; 6) Prolongations – prolonged pronunciations of a word. Interrater reliability will be calculated with Pearson’s correlation as well as percentages of exact overlap. Interratings of r = .70 and exact overlap = 60% will be set as threshold levels, in which lower values will lead to re-coding of the variable.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: Hypothesis 1: Each effort cue – hedges, word fillers, non-word fillers, delays, false starts and prolongations. Memory accuracy. For calculations of these variables, please see under heading “Procedure”.
Each effort cue as DV and memory accuracy as IV, with individual memories nested within participants.
We will use null hypothesis testing.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi: Interaction 3: Repetition, time, memory accuracy and retrieval effort. Retrieval effort is calculated as an effort index. That is, a variable computed by adding the effort cues (hedges, word fillers, non-word fillers, delays, false starts and/or prolongations) that have significant unique contribution to memory accuracy. For the other variables, see “Methods – description of essential elements”.
Repetition, time and memory accuracy as IVs, including their interactions. Retrieval effort as DV, with individual memories nested within participants.
We will use null hypothesis testing.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: We have planned a sample of N=50 with 25 participants in each group (repetition/control). Based on a pilot study, we expect each participant to provide about 70 statements (i.e. memories) about the witnessed event, at each interview. This will yield a total sample size of about 7000 memories.

Participants will be recruited at Stockholm University and other universities in the Stockholm area (KTH, Karolinska Institute, Södertörn university), as well as from the website www.studentkaninen.se. Posters will be placed at these locations to advertise the study. Data collection will be performed in a lab at Stockholm University with videotaped interviews.

A power analysis for a linear multiple regression with 7 predictors (accuracy, time, repetition and their interactions), a medium effect size and 95% power will require N=153. The planned study is expected to yield a sample over 45 times greater. Although the analyses we expect to run are multilevel rather than a linear regression, the sample size should result in adequate power. According to Snijders (2005), the sample size at the top level (memories, in this case) is the most important in multilevel models, of which our sample is expected to be N≈7000. 

We will use a greater sample size than required by the power analysis as we want to have data from several different participants.
Data collection will be terminated when 50 participants have completed both the first and second interview. Data will not be coded nor analyzed until all observations have been collected.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-fourth.fourth.ques: Hypothesis 5: Memory accuracy, retrieval effort, confidence. Retrieval effort is calculated as an effort index. That is, a variable computed by adding the effort cues (hedges, word fillers, non-word fillers, delays, false starts and/or prolongations) that have significant unique contribution to memory accuracy. For the other variables, see “Methods – description of essential elements”.
Memory accuracy as IV, retrieval effort as mediator, confidence as DV.
We will use null hypothesis testing.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques: Hypothesis 2: Repetition and retrieval effort. Retrieval effort is calculated as an effort index. That is, a variable computed by adding the effort cues (hedges, word fillers, non-word fillers, delays, false starts and/or prolongations) that have significant unique contribution to memory accuracy. For Repetition, see “Methods – description of essential elements”.

Only data from the second interview will be utilized, as repetition has not taken place before the first interview. Repetition as IV, Retrieval effort as DV, with individual memories nested within participants.
We will use null hypothesis testing.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-further.further.qu: Hypothesis 6: Repetition, memory quantity. For calculations of Repetition, see “Methods – description of essential elements”. Memory quantity will be calculated by summing the number of memories (i.e. statements) by each participant.
Only data from the second interview will be utilized, as repetition has not taken place before the first interview. Repetition as DV, Memory quantity as IV.
We will use null hypothesis testing.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
We will exclude participants who:
1) fail to complete both interviews
2) do not have correct or corrected-to-normal vision
3) correctly recognize any of the actors in the stimulus material (staged crime film)
4) do not complete the repetition task despite being assigned to the repetition group
5) do not speak fluent Swedish
6) are underage (under 18 years old)
